texts.shortText: A medium- to large-sized cladobranch, peach-coloured with multiple bushy cream-coloured secondary gills. The oral veil has long pointed papillae. The rhinophores are cream-coloured and have a central crown of papillae surrounding a longer single stalk. The rhinophoral sheaths are widely flared with a pale rim. The notum has clusters of scattered opaque white spots in paired patches. There is a narrow opaque white margin. The foot is peach-coloured with an opaque white margin. Juveniles are pale, translucent and smooth-bodied. There is a narrow opaque white marginal line which extends to the rhinophoral sheaths.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the Eastern Cape, 5â€“137 m in depth.
This species is usually found on reefs, in association with soft corals and sponges.
Thought to prey on the Multicoloured sea fan, Melithaea rubra.
This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colouration not yet known.

The peach coloration with opaque white spots is distinctive, as is the opaque white marginal line. Juveniles can be confused with pale morphs of the Purple soft coral lacedragon, Marionia sp.7, but are distinguished by having longer papillae on the oral veil, the smooth notum and the opaque white marginal line on widely flared rhinophoral sheaths.

Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 108).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 458).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 146).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 73).
